data.title: Slow stepping when debugging Typescript repos
data.body:
Investigate again why the stepping is slow when debuggin the Typescript repository (steps take 1 second). More details can be found here https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5645
fyi @egamma

data.title: run tests in electron renderer by default
data.body: Since a few weeks we now have `test-electron.sh` which runs our tests in a renderer process which is close the environment in which 90% of our code runs. Also, the allows up to give up the sometimes artificial separation between common and browser, e.g. for editor contributions which always run in a browser.

data.title: Unable to paste file, which was copied in another vscode instance
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1658949/24550872/678257c2-1620-11e7-8ba5-6e940a446707.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open two instances of VS Code. Copy a file in one instance.
2. Attempt to paste the file in the other VS Code instance.

The file is not pasted.

data.title: Unhelpful initial info message: "Some keyboard shortcuts have changed..."
data.body:
- VSCode Version: smoke test
- OS Version: macOS

When starting VS Code with a new `--user-data-dir` I get an unhelpful initial info message: "Some keyboard shortcuts have changed for my keyboard layout."

What are the keyboard shortcuts? Does it affect me? Can I do something about it?

A link to a page with further information would be helpful.

data.title: Extension Developers: Allow Variable Substitutions in Settings.config
data.body:
As an extension developer I would love if its possible to use the built in VSCode variable substitution in my own extension settings JSON config file, like task.json & launch.json
https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_variable-substitution

The ones of interest for me are `${workspaceRoot}` and `${workspaceRootFolderName}`

data.title: VSCode should detect characters like new line and tab ( \n , \t) in find and replace.
data.body:
VSCode should detect characters like new line and tab ( \n , \t) in find and replace.

Suppose I want to replace all tabs with new lines then how could I replace it.

data.title: Unchanged file showing unsaved indicator
data.body:
VSCode shows an indicator for files that are not different from their unsaved state.

Is this a Microsoft design choice?

I like to know that saving a file when the indicator is present means a new file will be written to the disk. So I think the indicator should only be shown when there is a valid diff of buffer vs. file on disk.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Fedora 22

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file
2. Make a modification
3. Manually revert the modification (*not via undo*)

data.title: Find files - files to include globbing bug
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.10.2
- OS Version:OSX10.11

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a folder setup of:
```
src
 - Portal
 - Portal.Tests
```
2. Put a *.cs file inside both folders
3. Do a search for `foo` with the glob set to `src/Portal/**/*.cs`
4. You will get results for files in Portal.Tests. This is incorrect, it should be searching only in Portal.

data.title: Ctrl+D changes search input for repeated content
data.body:
Version 1.11.0-insider
Commit 277dc8bdb99ac2ae820d5ee35d9fa2fedd65d0b1
Date 2017-03-31T08:31:42.609Z

Have the following file foo.txt
```
asdasdasd

sasdasd

asdasdasdasd
```
- select `das` on the first list
- Press Ctrl + D. Observe that the selection gets extended to 'dasdas' and that the next match is on line 3

data.title: JSON does not mark a tab inside a string as an error
data.body:
1. Have the following json: 
```json
{
  "a": "	"
}
```
2. JSON does not report an error (I have a tab inside the string)
3. JSON.parse does not allow tabs inside strings which leads to very confusing behavior and optimally we would highlight this user error

fyi @alexandrudima

data.title: Debugger intermittently hits/misses breakpoints in extension activation code (race?)
data.body:
Ok, I know this is going to sound really silly, but I've wasted 30 mins on this and tried everything and I cannot figure out what's happening.

I have a VS Code Extension written in TypeScript (Dart Code). I was doing some work on it this morning and everything was working fine - I was make changes, restarting, hitting breakpoints. All good.

At some point, the debugger just stopped hitting my breakpoints. It was definitely executing the new code, the breakpoints are listed on the left and highlighted in the editor, but execution does not pause.

I've tried many things, none of which has solved this, including:

- Reverting all my code changes to the last commit (when it worked)
- Restarting VS Code (the main IDE, not just extension host)
- Rebooting my PC
- Uninstalling my own extension from Code (though normally I get a warning that it's overwritten so I believe having it installed is a support scenario)
- Make trivial edits to the files to ensure any buffers are flushed
- Run `npm install` to make sure I don't have any mismatched package versions

I've even put a `console.log` as the first line in `activate` and stuck a breakpoint on it. When I run it, the text appears in the output, yet the breakpoint is not hit:

![Breakpoint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/24544675/1c2defee-15fc-11e7-8953-cdfc75eb38ae.png)

I haven't updated Code (or anything else) in the period between it working/not working; I've literally only modified a few lines of TypeScript in `extension.ts` (other than the troubleshooting listed above). I know this sounds impossible, but I'm stuck with how to debug further!

data.title: Snippet tabstop selecting content of previously entered variable only works when separated by space
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and load snippet for language javascript:
    ```json
    "import": {
      "prefix": "imp",
      "body": "import ${2:${1:module}} from '${1:module}'$0",
      "description": "Default import"
    }
    ```
2. Open .js file, type `imp`
3. Press `TAB`, type `styled-components` (you now have `import styled-components from 'styled-components'`)
4. Press `TAB` again, cursors don't move and you could now continue typing at the end of what you just typed. This is unexpected.

Expected:

4. Press `TAB` again, the first `styled-components` is selected and you can start typing to overwrite it, e.g. by pressing `TAB` and typing `styled`, creating `import styled from 'styled-components'`


The whole thing works as expected when the snippet body is this: `import ${2: ${1:module}} from '${1:module}'$0` - except that you then have a whitespace where you didn't want one.

data.title: Improve search performance and support Sublime's Go To Anywhere feature
data.body:
Searching file in VS Code is not very good, it always take time to response the result.

Also, one of the best feature of Sublime is its support to super quick search and go to any file, especially the new feature called "Go to anywhere". It would be nice if VS Code can support it.

![gotoanywhere](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1470309/24542397/a8aa80bc-1625-11e7-994e-d106fa89e23d.jpg)

data.title: launch.json shows stale warnings after deleting/closing
data.body:
I was working on a feature branch for my extension and switched back to master. Since I now had an invalid `launch.json` (it had values in that relate to the new feature that isn't on my master branch) I got warnings.

I closed `launch.json` and deleted it, then hit F5. I picked mt extensions option which resulted in a new `launch.json` being created; however it still shows warnings based on the old contents.

I suspect some state is hanging around when I deleted the file and also not being refreshed when `launch.json` is being re-created by hitting F5 (it's coming from `initialConfigurations` in `package.json` for my extension).

![launch.json](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/24542372/4b8ee846-15f3-11e7-9312-cd49cdf344d0.jpg)

data.title: SCM Icon blinking
data.body:
I get into an SCM icon blinking state

![blink](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/24541079/4637f4fc-15f6-11e7-8670-488b89b1522f.gif)

Looks like this is caused by this error message
```
git show :../../AppData/Roaming/Code - Insiders/User/settings.json
git show :../../AppData/Roaming/Code - Insiders/User/settings.json
fatal: '../../AppData/Roaming/Code - Insiders/User/settings.json' is outside repository

fatal: '../../AppData/Roaming/Code - Insiders/User/settings.json' is outside repository

```

Adding to March Milestone for discussion

data.title: Encoding auto guessing: Use buffer properly
data.body:
Related to #21416 
Fixed to use slice of the part of bytesRead.

Before the change, even if bytesRead is smaller than 512,the buffer of 512 byte whose last some bytes are uninitialized values is passed to `encoding.guessEncodingByBuffer`.
Maybe it cause weired encoding guessing.

data.title: Snippets started with "#" not worked
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider &  1.11.0
- OS Version:macOS 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write a snippet's started with "#", like "#ifdef"
2. The snippet showed in typing "#" then "ctrl+space", and in the "Insert Snippet" command.
3.  not showed in intelligence.
4. not showed in "#if + ctrl + space" or "#i + ctrl + space".
5. cannot expanded by the "tab".
6. other snippets work correctly.
7. same snippet with a different prefix, works correctly.

use a clean build without any other extension or custom preference.

data.title: [scss] --- should be marked as error
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.10.2 - OS Version: 10.12.3 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a Sass file 2. Add an `import` statement to a file that exists 3. Editor incorrectly flags an error - `[scss] { expected` 4. This is the correct syntax - http://sass-lang.com/guide#topic-5 (Note if I edit `settings.json` and add `"scss.validate": false` the error goes away but that is because ALL validation is disabled.

data.title: Format indentation issue?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3
- Extension: Go 0.6.57
- Extension add: goreturns/gofmt

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type code without indentation.
2. Leave the cursor after the code.
3. Format the code (shift+option+f or save when formatOnSave=true).
4. The cursor will select the last element of that line.
5. The element selected will be replaced when press return key to change line, so that the code is broken.

![fmt1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25337614/24533132/2585cfd4-15f8-11e7-947e-b9846e9f0b6b.gif)

Is there any settings to fix that problem? Really annoying.

data.title: Autohide output panel when autoshown
data.body:
e.g. when reporting git information on commit/push/etc. the output panel will show itself, and only go away when the user takes action. 

This for me means hitting ctrl+` twice after every git operation to get the output out of my way.

It'd be lovely if it had an autohide behavior when displayed passively, and a sticky behavior when brought up intentionally (via key command).

Alternatively, a push-pin icon for establishing its sticky/non-sticky behavior would also work great.

Thanks in advance!

Best
Michael

data.title: Have a way to do editor history navigation across split views
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a program source file
2. Edit keyboard shortcuts (or presumably anything that splits the window in two)
3. Go back to the program source file, click on a function call, and press F12 (editor.action.goToDeclaration)
4. Do some other stuff in the other window split
5. Come back, and try to go back to the call site in a single step by pressing Ctrl+- (workbench.action.navigateBack) or Ctrl+U (cursorUndo)

It actually takes several steps, because it takes you back thru every significant cursor change.  There should be a way to navigate only the tag stack, like Ctrl+] and Ctrl+T in Vim.
